exam_preparation_tips.human: How can I create an effective study schedule?
exam_preparation_tips.assistant: To create an effective study schedule, start by listing all the subjects you need to study. Allocate time for each subject based on its difficulty and importance. Include regular breaks and ensure you stick to your schedule. Use tools like calendars or apps to keep track of your progress.

exam_preparation_tips.human: How To Prepare for NEET and JEE Simultaneously
exam_preparation_tips.assistant:
NEET and JEE are both some of the toughest exams in India, there is no doubt that one can prepare for both of these exams simultaneously. The real trick lies in hard work and dedication. Students should be ready to put in lots of effort and should be disciplined in their approach.
On one hand, the JEE Mains exam is conducted to grant admission to engineering colleges, and the NEET exam is conducted for admissions to Medical colleges.
Although it is possible, it‚Äôs not an easy deal. It will require your full attention and patience. To prepare for JEE Mains and NEET, certain points should be kept in mind. It will surely help you prepare well and score good marks in both exams.
Can Students Prepare NEET and JEE At the Same Time?
Students can get ready for both NEET and JEE simultaneously. If you excel in Math and Biology but are unsure whether to focus on JEE or NEET, you can opt for PCMB and prepare for both exams concurrently. Some students have successfully passed both NEET and JEE in the same year.
How to Prepare for IIT NEET and JEE Both?
The following are the effective Strategies for Simultaneous Preparation of NEET and JEE:
1. Develop a Well-Structured Study Schedule
Initiate your preparation by creating a comprehensive study schedule that strategically allocates time for both NEET and JEE subjects. Emphasize an equitable distribution of time across Physics, Chemistry, Biology, and Mathematics.
2. Assemble Essential Study Materials
Ensure you have all the necessary study materials, encompassing textbooks, reference books, and online resources relevant to both NEET and JEE. Specifically, pay attention to Biology by utilizing the National Council of Educational Research and Training (NCERT) materials.
3. Integrate Physics and Chemistry Topics
Given the substantial overlap in the syllabi of Physics and Chemistry for NEET and JEE, consider integrating your study sessions for these subjects. This approach can streamline your preparation process.
4. Understand the Distinct Exam Patterns
Recognize the nuanced differences in the examination patterns between NEET and JEE. While both exams are predominantly Multiple Choice Question (MCQ) based, it‚Äôs crucial to note that JEE incorporates numerical type questions. Familiarize yourself with the diverse number of questions allocated to each subject.
5. Mock Tests and Past Papers
Boost your confidence and familiarity with the exam patterns by engaging in regular practice with mock tests and solving previous years‚Äô question papers for both NEET and JEE. This practice aids in effective time management and facilitates the identification of your strengths and weaknesses.
6. Promptly Clarify Doubts
Maintain a proactive approach to your learning by seeking clarification for any challenging concepts or doubts. Utilize the expertise of your teachers, mentors, or online resources. Addressing uncertainties early on contributes significantly to building a robust foundation in each subject.
7. Regularly Review Key Concepts
Reinforce your understanding and retention of studied topics through consistent and regular revision. Incorporate dedicated time slots in your study timetable for this purpose, and consider creating succinct summary notes or flashcards to facilitate quick reviews.
8. Access Guidance and Support from Experienced Teachers
Consider enrolling in a coaching program, be it online or offline, to gain valuable insights and guidance from experienced teachers. They can provide you with effective strategies and the necessary support to navigate the challenges of preparing for both NEET and JEE concurrently.

exam_preparation_tips.human: How should a dropper prepare for neet?
exam_preparation_tips.assistant: First thing to do as a dropper (which I strongly recommend) is that you should join a course. Online is good for you if you have self control. If you don't have self control and a good offline institute is nearby, you should go for it if you can afford. Even if you think you know everything already , it is better to have guidance along the way , plus you always learn something new which will be helpful. Hearing concepts from the teachers is very helpful aswell since it will stick in your memory longer. Even in exam I could recall what my teachers said since it was only a few months ago that they taught me. Another important thing is that do not join too many courses. Join as much as you can handle. I joined Aakash offline course and then joined NEETprep target batch for question practice aswell (practiced 22k questions) , but I couldn't give many tests on NEETprep due to lack of time. So , be careful./nI will try to enlist a few points in this answer about common mistakes commited by droppers. First you should identify your shortcomings out of these and accept them and then try to stop them. If you don't commit that particular mistake you can skip to the next point./nThinking too much about the past : here I'm talking about students who may be overconfident since they were close to selection the previous year. I saw this among others and also with me for a few weeks of my preparation, and some of my batchmates even cared about marks in NEET 21 after 6‚Äì7 months of preparation when the next NEET 22 was so close. Keep this clear in your mind that whatever you scored previous year does not matter. It does not mean that you would improve a lot without hardwork or that you would score more than others or that you are smarter. People forget almost everything within a span of a month or two , so it's better you work hard to improve your score much more the next year. It is good that you were close to selection last year but prepare like everything depends on it so that you can get your maximum output./nWorrying too much about the past : this is different from the first point, here I'm talking about students who worry about how many drops they've taken , or that their score wasn't good last year in comparison to others who are dropping this year , or that they wasted 11th and 12th completely , etc. Once you've decided that you want to drop a year for your preparation, you should forget about your past , whether it was good or bad. Focus only on your goal ahead and think about how you can boost your preparation every day. Do not think about others and focus on yourself since your competition is very huge , not just the people around you./nAiming at the bare minimum : I've seen droppers thinking just about selection in a govt college. I would say everyone should aim high. Set a dream college and work hard for that dream , do not lose your goal. Since you have a few months at hand , rather than thinking for the bare minimum you should score as much as you can without setting any target other than 720/720 so that you can get any college you want. My teachers always said that since you've got an extra year for preparation without any school or distractions , your target should be 720./nReading only theory : This is a mistake I committed during my 11th and 12th. I read theory but did not practice many questions. I did only the homework given by my teachers and that was all for question practice. I didn't even do PYQs. I believe you should focus equally on question practice and theory lectures/reading if you're starting from scratch on a topic. Since I already had clear concepts in theory in a few topics I revised briefly and jumped to question practice immediately in those topics , but that was not true for all topics. You also need to identify that what you should do for each topic. Whatever you do , question practice is very important in all subjects to know the applications of the concepts you study./nNot Making your own notes : This is one big mistake I saw droppers committing , they joined offline coaching , attended all classes and yet did not write much in their notebooks saying that they already have notes. My personal belief is that writing everything you can makes you retain stuff for a longer time, plus what else there is to do when you're attending a class , if you write it'll stop you from distracting yourself. Even in biology , even if you read only NCERT still you should just write what you hear in your class so that you retain it. Then at home you can read NCERT. If you're attending a class don't just sit without writing./nNeglecting Biology & Chemistry : It is very common that droppers think since they scored low in physics in their previous attempt(s) , they need to work hard in physics and then their exam will be cleared. But if you focus solely on 1 or 2 subjects and not on all the subjects it is sure that you'll score less. So focus on all the subjects and be sure to practice questions in all subjects adequately. You can adjust the proportion of questions practiced according to your marks in tests but never leave any subject unless you are scoring full marks consistently in that subject(which is not possible)/nNot having a Proper Plan(Long term) : This is a major issue , and droppers lose track of time if they don't have a proper long term plan. I personally joined offline coaching (Aakash Janakpuri) , so they set the long term schedule for me including revision and adequate time to do full mock tests after revision. But even if you're preparing online , be sure to have a schedule and stick to it no matter what. If you have joined a course/test series it is better to prepare according to their schedule./nNot Setting Short term targets : Along with a long term schedule , setting daily and weekly targets is very much important as well. Plan your week. Plan that what you will do every single day and try your best to complete that target. Try to leave a day or two every week for revision/backlog but I highly recommend you do not leave any backlog. I personally used to set targets in my mind for every 2‚Äì3 days and sometimes daily targets. I did questions of a chapter taught in class as soon as possible and didn't leave many backlogs. Rather than accumulating backlogs I'll do easy questions in advance if possible , if my schedule is tight later on and I have time before the topic is finished./nNot Giving Regular Tests : Along with weekly/fortnightly targets , tests are also important at about the same intervals. For tests , I followed Aakash Schedule. They scheduled offline tests at regular intervals. Plus if I had time in between , I attempted Neetprep tests(A course I joined online for question practice). But you don't need to focus too much on the source , trust the process not the resource. I believe all reputed coaching materials are good for NEET. If you're studying in that particular institute it makes it easier for you to get the best output from the tests and questions. Another thing tests can do is boost your morale after your hardwork. I personally preferred giving tests every 2 weeks and I studied very extensively for those tests to score good. There were other tests which I gave in between sometimes , many times the score wasn't great due to lack of time , but it motivates me even more to work harder./nNo proper Error Analysis : I personally did this mistake even in my drop year. From my package I circled the errors I made but didn't write a proper solution anywhere. And in my NEET 2021 preparation I didn't even bat an eye towards my errors. However , I realised late in my drop year that I need to analyse errors properly, for which I made a mistake notebook while revising. The mistakes help you a lot and if you've written a proper solution somewhere , it helps you recall quickly the approach for that question, since it is written by you. Plus when the exam was near , I revised only my mistakes and the formulae which I forgot./nFocusing too much on Difficult Questions : I have seen many serious droppers committing this particular mistake. They study too much for doing very difficult questions and they quickly move on to the difficult questions without properly doing the easy and moderate questions. This might induce a fear of that topic aswell if you find that you can't do any questions. For the past 3 years we've noticed that the complete exam was filled with easy and moderate questions only. And even before that hardly 2‚Äì3 difficult questions were asked sometimes , others were easy or moderate only. So until you have mastered all concepts from the NCERT and revised moderate questions several times , do not move on to difficult questions. And do not focus on a particular chapter/topic too much if your other topics are weak. This is very important , please take this seriously./nFocusing less on Rote Learning : Everyone knows that there are certain things in the NCERT (all subjects) which do not involve any logic and you just need to learn them anyhow. I have seen students leave these for the end or to not learn these at all. If it has been asked in the previous years or it can be asked (You can consult a teacher for that), then you should learn it. And don't leave it for the end , you won't have time. Just keep revising it throughout your preparation. Make a chart or a table and stick it on a wall so that you see it everyday. Use any mnemonics or tricks to learn such things but learn them quickly and revise them so that you have less to worry about at the end. Don't worry too much since people with average memory can retain that much for the exam. You don't need to be extraordinary to learn what is asked in NEET./nSpeed Before Accuracy : I did this mistake for a few mock tests. I saw other students who were very quick in doing questions and thought that I should try that aswell. But please note that accuracy comes before speed. First focus on doing the questions correctly, speed will come automatically. Don't rush through the exam. Plus now that biology asked could be tricky and lengthy (2022) and you have 20 minutes extra aswell , you need to focus on accuracy more. If someone is doing the questions very quickly it may be a result of more practice or it may be an act of stupidity. Don't try to do it yourself./nThese are all the common mistakes I saw which are committed by droppers. Ofcourse these are committed by those who are serious about their studies. If you're not serious and just wasting your time watching YouTube vlogs of NEET aspirants then you're doomed. If you know of any other common mistake please comment and I will reply if I can be of any help./nDetermination is important along with the strategy , avoiding these mistakes and having good teachers. I used to practice questions on my phone even during the time which I travelled. I used to read NCERT on my phone while traveling and I did questions even while eating , on my phone . Time is less and hence utilise as much as you can. I personally cannot sleep less than 6‚Äì7 hrs a day, hence I had to work efficiently./nThe drop year can cause a lot of stress and anxiety which accumulates over the years if you've taken multiple drops. Be sure to have some time for your family aswell (20‚Äì30 mins a day is good) so that you can have some relaxation. They'll talk to you nicely and try to motivate you when they know that they see you working hard this year and see a change in you./nAll the best from my side to all droppers! Do your best without worrying about the results too much.

exam_preparation_tips.human: How can I prepare for the NEET exam effectively?
exam_preparation_tips.assistant: So here are a few tips which can really help you to crack the exam :/nThere is no substitute of hardwork, cliche but it's the reality u can't replace it ./nConsistency is the only key ,u don't need to study 15 -16 hrs a day study 7‚Äì8 hrs everyday ,by study I mean productive study not passive reading and learning ./nDiscipline & habit >>>>>>motivation by watching videos ,trust me I also fell in th trap of this but this is a very short term help if u want something to work for the longer run make a habit ki Haan muhje toh 7 ghante pdhna hi hi h roz ka koi science nhi h isme .self motivation lao and sirf mbbs, college ki hi sapne mat dekho bas yeh socho ki kaise neet mein marks acche laye that's it./nDon't fall for youtube didi bhaiya , I myself cleared neet I know every single line of ncert of bio ,chemistry but does that makes me an experienced teacher NO !!!! It's not just about knowledge it's about how u present it and give it to students. Study with teachers who are well experienced and with whom ur vibe matches ./nNotes are the biggest help in the last time because when u see a question and u feel to revise the concept only notes will help ,and ur handmade notes are the best except that all the notes present online lacks material idk how to explain but simply they won't help so best is to make it by urself ./nTaking breaks is very normal everyone does, if one day u don't feel like studying don't do it leave it . Let me tell that doesn't mean that u can take 1 day break every 3‚Äì4 days once or twice in a month is fine ../nNo regrets if u are taking a break make sure u don't think about the studies because fayda nhi h anyway u are not going to study so no regrets if u are taking a day off make sure to enjoy to ur fullest ./nRelax after test. Ik how tiring and hectic it is before the test and during also so make sure to take a good 4 hrs rest after test and again start with a fresh mind/nEvery test will teach u something and it really changes u as a student at that time u don't understand because the change is slight but when u look at it how u started and how are u doing it shows how much u have changed .so give space to ur mind to change/nMake sure u learn from ur batchmates and maintain a healthy competition with them it should never be toxic , ur brain should always be ready to learn and also be humble so that it gets easy for you to learn/nAlot of things are still left but that's it for the answer it's very long but I hope it helps if u have any doubt and facing any problem just message or comment I will definitely help byeee see u supersoon üòÄ

exam_preparation_tips.human: How do I start preparing for the NEET for 10 months?
exam_preparation_tips.assistant: Hello . If you are sincerely preparing for neet 10 months are just sufficient to get any govnt mbbs College./nHere are some steps that i found common among all neet Aspirants ‚Äî/nFirstly download the neet syllabus from neet website./nThoroughly read the syllabus ./nBuy yourself some pyqs go through the paper pattern ./nBuy new ncert books ie newest edition because a lot of syllabus reduced this year from ncert./nConsider ncert biology of 11 ‚Äî12 as your holy books revise them as much as possible ./nBiology itself will give you 360 marks ./nFor physics you can buy any books as available on google ./nAlso ncert is imp for physics too. Do solve the questions given in ncert of physics ./nChemistry again ncert is very imp for inorganic organic and solve questions of physical chemistry ./nJoin some good coaching tests./nConsistency is most imp ./nSolve dpps give regular tests even if you are not prepare still give the test ./nIt will maintain your consistency/nLastly don't panic./nJust remember there's a competition . And only hardwork beats talent./nBbye/nGoodluck !!

exam_preparation_tips.human: How To Balance Board Exams And NEET Preparation
exam_preparation_tips.assistant: Preparing for both NEET and board exams gets a bit challenging for a majority of candidates. Here are a few tips that can be followed to balance your preparation:/nCover NCERT textbooks thoroughly, as many topics overlap in the Board exams and preparation for NEET./nKeep the Board exam topics aligned and study one of them with the simultaneous solution of the NEET-level questions./nBuild a very strong base for theoretical application in board answers and subjective application in NEET./nDescriptive writing can be the focus closer to the boards. Practice objective writing closer to the NEET exam.

exam_preparation_tips.human: How to Prepare for NEET from Class 11
exam_preparation_tips.assistant: The foremost strategy for preparing for NEET 2025 from Class 11 is to get familiar with the syllabus and be calm by it. The curriculum of Class 11 can be a bit intimidating for many, but it is in the best interest of the candidates to deal with it tactfully. Candidates must acquaint themselves with the NEET Class 11 chapters to develop a preparation strategy./nDevelop a comprehensive study schedule/nFrom the moment candidates are familiar with the syllabus, they should develop an effective study schedule to prepare for NEET 2025. NEET 2025 study plan should be structured so that there is no monotonous work and recreation time is included. Studying time must be in short bursts, especially during the time of the day when one feels most productive. The study plan should be organized and re-evaluated as time progresses. Higher priority must be given to the topics which carry more weight in the NEET 2025 exam. Such topics from each subject have been listed for candidates‚Äô reference purposes/nImportant Topics/nPhysics/nKinematics/nLaws of Motion/nWork, Energy, and Power/nRotational Motion/nOscillations and Waves/nHeat and Thermodynamics/nChemistry/nMole Concept/nStoichiometry/nChemical Bonding/nStates of matter/nThermodynamics/nHydrogen and S-block/nOrganic and Hydrocarbons/nBiology/nDiversity in the Living World/nCell Cycle/nCell Division/nBiomolecules/nStructural Organisation in Plants and Animals/nHuman Physiology/nKnow which books to choose from/nFor Class 11 students preparing for NEET 2025, NCERT is the most crucial resource. The candidates should be well-versed in every concept in the book, including formulas and numerals. Once through with the NCERT, candidates must then try and solve questions from the curriculum of the best books for NEET class 11 mentioned below./nObjective Physics Vol. 1 by Arihant/nObjective Chemistry Vol. 1 by Arihant/nA to Z Biology for NEET Class 11 by Cengage/nStudy the topics chronologically/nCandidates preparing for NEET from Class 11 must maintain a chronological order of topics while studying. Several topics for NEET 2025 are interrelated, and studying accordingly will help better understand the underlying concepts and prove helpful during revision../nIdentify the strong and weak areas/nStarting Class 11, aspirants must make it a point to be familiar with the topics they have a strong command over and the topics they find to be more challenging. Accordingly, the study hours need to be divided among these so that the syllabus can be covered effectively./nPractice Regularly/nA regular schedule is the most important aspect of preparing for NEET 2025 from Class 11 onwards. Regular practice should encompass solving numerical, practising formulas, schematic diagrams, etc./nRevision is of utmost necessity/nAspirants must develop a habit of regular revision while preparing for NEET from Class 11. The syllabus of Class 11 tends to be forgotten by candidates once they've been promoted to a higher class, so they must schedule revisions accordingly./nTry and Solve Mock Tests/nFor NEET aspirants it is a good idea to identify and solve the questions from the Class 11 part so that they can determine how much time they need to solve a particular type of question and become familiar with the types of questions they may encounter. The practice of mock tests is also a great way for candidates to improve their time management skills. In view of the fact that NEET 2025 mock tests cover the entire syllabus of Class 11, candidates in Class 11 should strongly consider taking them.

exam_preparation_tips.human: How do toppers prepare for the exam?
exam_preparation_tips.assistant: Making a systematic timetable for NEET 2025 preparation is one of the key tips given by most of the toppers. The proper NEET 2025 study time table helps the candidates in boosting their preparation./nWhen asked about the NEET preparation strategy, NEET 2020 topper, Soyeb Aftab, (AIR 1) said, ‚ÄúWhen schools were open I used to go to school from 7 AM to 2 PM, then from 2:30 I had my coaching. I used to get released from the coaching at around 6:30-7 PM. After that, I used to be so exhausted that I could devote 3-4 hours to self-study.‚Äù ‚ÄúSo to cover up for this I used to study 10-12 hours on holidays. When the lockdown was imposed nationwide I got more time for self-study. Then I used to give 10-12 hours to my preparation every day‚Äù he added./nCandidates often search for 'how to prepare for NEET from class 11'. NEET 2020, AIR 16, Bhawana Manasa said, ‚ÄúI have started my NEET preparations in class 11. I followed my college time-table for studying which includes weekly exams and preparatory classes.‚Äù/nTo emerge with flying colours in NEET 2025, candidates must know what, when and how to study. Thus, making a comprehensive and able-to-do timetable is a must for NEET 2025 preparations.

NEET topper, Tanmay Gupta said, ‚ÄúIn the last month, I was more focused on giving more NEET mock tests for the full syllabus. It was NCERT textbook revision and giving mock tests. While in the earlier days, I used to prepare through NCERT textbooks and revision notes provided by the teachers. In the last few days, my focus shifted to taking as many NEET mock tests as possible.‚Äù/n‚ÄúDuring the early preparation for NEET from Class 11 and 12, I studied a lot of things and tried to cover every topic. However, in the last few months of NEET UG preparations, I filtered the subjects of what‚Äôs more important and relevant and focused on those topics. In the last month of preparations, I also focused on mock tests and NCERT for NEET UG.‚Äù, said NEET 2021, AIR 5, Suyash Arora./nThus, solving previous years question papers and mock tests helps in evaluating the preparation levels of the candidates familiarised with the NEET 2025 exam pattern. Candidates are advised to practice completing the mock tests before time to develop a proper time-management strategy.

exam_preparation_tips.human: How to crack NEET in first attempt 2025
exam_preparation_tips.assistant: When starting to prepare for an NEET UG exam, the first step should be to prepare a timetable that will help candidates plan their time topic-wise or subject-wise. It should be ensured by the aspirants that the timetable is followed religiously. The timetable should be prepared to cover the topics which can be revised multiple times. This strategy will provide candidates with a clear picture of their schedule in the forthcoming months and will help in cracking NTA NEET 2025 in the first attempt./nDivide your time- Candidates should divide their time in such a way that an adequate amount of time is given to each session while preparing a strategy of how to crack NEET-UG in the first attempt. Prioritize the important topics and study them thoroughly. Make sure to take small breaks when studying for long hours./nSet deadlines- Deciding when to complete one topic and the whole syllabus will be beneficial considering there are few months left for the NEET exam. Candidates should set shorter and larger goals for them at the same time. Shorter goals will help candidates in knowing the topics covered each day while the longer goals will help in understanding how much they need to cover to crack NEET UG 2025 in the first attempt./nStudy Material- Collect the relevant study material to prepare for NEET 2025. There is no dearth of books in the market but for competitive exams like NEET, one should know the significant study material. The NEET NCERT textbooks for Class 11 and 12 are recommended as the best books for NEET./nStudy and examine/nAspirants of NEET UG 2025 must understand that it is a competitive exam, therefore, mugging up the concepts will not work. The NEET questions require a basic understanding of topics for which one needs to study hard but also smartly. After covering each topic examine where one stands and clear doubts at that time itself./nComprehensive Study- Try to make notes of every topic that is being covered to understand it better. This will be beneficial at the time of revision. Since the NCERT textbooks cover most of the NEET syllabus 2025, candidates must ensure that they are familiar with every topic of NCERT from end to end./nEvaluate your performance- Take some time out to revise the topics. Make flashcards if aspirants have a problem retaining the concepts. Make a note of all the doubts that are coming along the way and get help from the guides and books. This will help scrutinize the performance of each day and in this one can be his/her best judgment./nSubject-wise Preparation Tips/nThe three subjects that make up NEET are Physics, Chemistry and Biology. Students should arrange their schedules to allow them to review two subjects per day. This can be done in a certain way:/nPhysics/nPhysics numericals play an important role in exam since most medical students get apprehended while looking at the numerical. Either they completely skip the questions or attempt it incorrectly. However, looking at the recent trend of the Physics section it seems numerical plays an important role in scoring good marks in NEET. Hence, students after studying any chapter should solve around 30-40 numercials containing particular topics in that chapter. You can prepare notes for all the formulas and tabulate them in one notebook./nChemistry/nThe whole Chemistry syllabus of Class 11 and 12 is divided into three sections - Organic, Inorganic and Physical Chemistry. For Physical Chemistry, solve numerical questions 10-15 whenever you are revising a particular chapter for better conceptual clarity. For Inorganic chemistry focus on NCERT thoroughly. Similarly, in organic chemistry practice basic mechanisms and conversions in a rough notebook./nBiology/nBiology is divided into Botany and Zoology, comprising 50% of the NEET exam. Hence, it becomes one of the most important sections. However, looking at previous years' trends Biology section comes easy and often is one of the highest scoring out of all the three sections. All you need to do is study smart. Dedicate your time separately to the Botany and Zoology chapters. Thoroughly revise NCERT. Diagrams and tables from NCERTS need to be practised thoroughly./nPlease note that this strategy may or may not work for everyone. One has to understand and analyse their weaknesses and strengths and consistency towards NEET exam preparation./nPractice mock tests/nTaking mock tests becomes essential to know how to crack NEET in the first attempt as mock tests give an exam day experience. This will attune candidates to the pressure of the exam and complete the NEET paper in three hours. The mock tests should be of the same time frame as the NEET UG exam./nSolve previous year papers- Practicing last year‚Äôs question papers is essential for candidates aiming to crack NEET-UG in the first attempt. NEET question papers will help in understanding the level of the exam and the important topics./nRevise incorrectly attempted questions- After each mock test, make a note of wrong answers and start working on the weak areas. Make sure that there are no recurring mistakes. This will increase the candidates‚Äô proficiency in the NEET UG exam.
